desc: Detects commands by AWS Simple Systems Manager (SSM) scripted events.  This rule can be tuned to exclude any known scripts to detect unknown activity. Detects file writes by AWS Simple Systems Manager (SSM) scripted events.  This rule can be tuned to exclude any known scripts to detect unknown activity.  An authenticated AWS user with necessary privileges could run arbitrary commands as root without EC2 system credentials.  For use in conjunction with rule "SSM Send Command".

desc: Anonymous, public read access to a container and its blobs can be enabled in Azure Blob storage. It grants read-only access to these resources without sharing the account key, and without requiring a shared access signature. It is recommended not to provide anonymous access to blob containers until, and unless, it is strongly desired. A shared access signature token should be used for providing controlled and timed access to blob containers. If no anonymous access is needed on the storage account, it’s recommended to set allowBlobPublicAccess false.
rule: Azure Access Level creation attempt for Blob Container Set to Public
tags: MITRE T1530 data from cloud storage object

desc: Anonymous, public read access to a container and its blobs can be enabled in Azure Blob storage. It grants read-only access to these resources without sharing the account key, and without requiring a shared access signature. It is recommended not to provide anonymous access to blob containers until, and unless, it is strongly desired. A shared access signature token should be used for providing controlled and timed access to blob containers. If no anonymous access is needed on the storage account, it’s recommended to set allowBlobPublicAccess false.
rule: Azure Access Level for Blob Container Set to Public
tags: MITRE T1530 data from cloud storage

desc:
The Azure platform allows a SQL server to be created as a service. Enabling auditing at the server level ensures that all existing and newly created databases on the SQL server instance are audited. Auditing policy applied on the SQL database does not override auditing policy and settings applied on the particular SQL server where the database is hosted.
Auditing tracks database events and writes them to an audit log in the Azure storage account. It also helps to maintain regulatory compliance, understand database activity, and gain insight into discrepancies and anomalies that could indicate business concerns or suspected security violations.
rule: Azure Auditing on SQL Server Has Been Disabled
tags: MITRE T1070 indicator removal on host

desc: A blob has been created in a storage container.
tags: MITRE T1537 transfer data to cloud account

desc: A blob has been deleted from a storage container.
A container ACL has been modified.
tags: MITRE T1222 file and directory permissions modification

desc: A Container has been created.
tags: MITRE T1053.007 scheduled task job container orchestration job

desc: A Container has been deleted.

Multi-factor authentication requires an individual to present a minimum of two separate forms of authentication before access is granted. Multi-factor authentication provides additional assurance that the individual attempting to gain access is who they claim to be. With multi-factor authentication, an attacker would need to compromise at least two different authentication mechanisms, increasing the difficulty of compromise and thus reducing the risk.
rule: Azure Deactivate MFA for User Access
tags: MITRE T1098.005 account manipulation device registration

desc: Storage accounts should be configured to deny access to traffic from all networks (including internet traffic). Access can be granted to traffic from specific Azure Virtual networks, allowing a secure network boundary for specific applications to be built. Access can also be granted to public internet IP address ranges, to enable connections from specific internet or on-premises clients. When network rules are configured, only applications from allowed networks can access a storage account. When calling from an allowed network, applications continue to require proper authorization (a valid access key or SAS token) to access the storage account.
rule: Azure Default Network Access Rule for Storage Account Set to Allow
tags: MITRE T1530 data from cloud storage

desc: A diagnostic setting controls how a diagnostic log is exported. By default, logs are retained only for 90 days. Diagnostic settings should be defined so that logs can be exported and stored for a longer duration in order to analyze security activities within an Azure subscription.
rule: Azure Diagnostic Setting Has Been Disabled
tags: MITRE T1070 indicator removal on host

desc: A function app has been deleted.
tags: MITRE T1578 modify cloud compute infrastructure

rule: Azure Function App Deployment Slot Deleted

desc: A function app host key has been deleted.
rule: Azure Function App Host Key Deleted

desc: A function key has been deleted.

The potential security problem with using RDP over the Internet is that attackers can use various brute force techniques to gain access to Azure Virtual Machines. Once the attackers gain access, they can use a virtual machine as a launch point for compromising other machines on an Azure Virtual Network or even attack networked devices outside of Azure.
rule: Azure RDP Access Is Allowed from The Internet
tags: MITRE T1021.001 remote services remote desktop protocol

desc: Remembering Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for devices and browsers allows users to have the option to by-pass MFA for a set number of days after performing a successful sign-in using MFA. This can enhance usability by minimizing the number of times a user may need to perform two-step verification on the same device. However, if an account or device is compromised, remembering MFA for trusted devices may affect security. Hence, it is recommended that users not be allowed to bypass MFA.
rule: Azure Remember MFA for User Access on Devices
tags: MITRE T1098.005 account manipulation device registration

desc: The potential security problem with using SSH over the Internet is that attackers can use various brute force techniques to gain access to Azure Virtual Machines. Once the attackers gain access, they can use a virtual machine as a launch point for compromising other machines on the Azure Virtual Network or even attack networked devices outside of Azure.
rule: Azure SSH Access Is Allowed from The Internet

desc: The secure transfer option enhances the security of a storage account by only allowing requests to the storage account by a secure connection. For example, when calling REST APIs to access storage accounts, the connection must use HTTPS. Any requests using HTTP will be rejected when 'secure transfer required' is enabled. When using the Azure files service, connection without encryption will fail, including scenarios using SMB 2.1, SMB 3.0 without encryption, and some flavors of the Linux SMB client. Because Azure storage doesn’t support HTTPS for custom domain names, this option is not applied when using a custom domain name.
rule: Azure Secure Transfer Required Set to Disabled
tags: MITRE T1537 transfer data to cloud account

desc: Vulnerability Assessment setting 'Periodic recurring scans' schedules periodic (weekly) vulnerability scanning for the SQL server and corresponding Databases. Periodic and regular vulnerability scanning provides risk visibility based on updated known vulnerability signatures and best practices.
rule: Azure Server Vulnerability Assessment on SQL Server Has Been Removed
tags: MITRE T1070 indicator removal on host

Unless Azure Active Directory is running as an identity provider for third-party applications, do not allow users to use their identity outside of the cloud environment. User profiles contain private information such as phone numbers and email addresses which could then be sold off to other third parties without requiring any further consent from the user.
rule: Azure Users Can Consent to Apps Accessing Company Data on Their Behalf
tags: MITRE T1528 steal application access token

desc: This rule detects base64 encoded ELF executables in command line arguments.  Base64 can be used to encode binary data for transfer to ASCII-only command lines.  Attackers can leverage this technique in various exploits to load shellcode and evade detection.

desc: Storage accounts should be configured to deny access to traffic from all networks (including internet traffic). Access can be granted to traffic from specific Azure Virtual networks, allowing a secure network boundary for specific applications to be built. Access can also be granted to public internet IP address ranges, to enable connections from specific internet or on-premises clients. When network rules are configured, only applications from allowed networks can access a storage account. When calling from an allowed network, applications continue to require proper authorization (a valid access key or SAS token) to access the storage account.
rule: Creation attempt Azure Default Network Access Rule for Storage Account Set to Allow

desc: The secure transfer option enhances the security of a storage account by only allowing requests to the storage account by a secure connection. For example, when calling REST APIs to access storage accounts, the connection must use HTTPS. Any requests using HTTP will be rejected when 'secure transfer required' is enabled. When using the Azure files service, connection without encryption will fail, including scenarios using SMB 2.1, SMB 3.0 without encryption, and some flavors of the Linux SMB client. Because Azure storage doesn’t support HTTPS for custom domain names, this option is not applied when using a custom domain name.
rule: Creation attempt Azure Secure Transfer Required Set to Disabled

desc: Detect updating password policy not preventing reuse of the last 4 passwords.
rule: Update Account Password Policy Not Preventing Reuse of Last 4 Passwords

desc: Detect updating password policy not requiring a minimum length of 14 characters.
rule: Update Account Password Policy Not Requiring 14 Characters

desc: Detect updating password policy not requiring a minimum length of 7 characters.
rule: Update Account Password Policy Not Requiring 7 Characters

desc: Detect updating password policy not requiring the use of an lowercase letter
rule: Update Account Password Policy Not Requiring Lowercase

desc: Detect updating password policy not requiring the use of a number
rule: Update Account Password Policy Not Requiring Number

desc: Detect updating password policy not requiring the use of a symbol
rule: Update Account Password Policy Not Requiring Symbol

desc: Detect updating password policy not requiring the use of an uppercase letter
rule: Update Account Password Policy Not Requiring Uppercase

desc: Detect updating the name and description of a custom action target in Security Hub.
Detect modifying a role.
Detect the update of an autoscaling group associated with with a load balancer which is not using health checks.
rule: Update Autoscaling Group without ELB Health Checks

desc: Detect updates to a Lambda function code.
tags: MITRE T1543 create or modify system process

desc: Detect updates to a Lambda function configuration.
tags: MITRE T1543 create or modify system process

desc: Detect package repositories get updated
tags: MITRE T1053.006 scheduled task job systemd timers

desc: Detect the changing of the password for root.
Detect updates of the password for a user.
Detect enabling or disabling of a standard control.
This rule detects create/modify/delete operations on users
Detect a user accessing Okta admin section
Detect a user accessing an app via Okta
rule: User accessing app via single sign on Okta

desc: Detect a user password change in Okta
rule: User changing password in to Okta

desc: Detect a user who has been activated in Okta
rule: User has been activated in Okta

desc: Detect a user who has been deactivated in Okta
rule: User has been deactivated in Okta

desc: Detect a user who has been locked out in Okta
rule: User has been locked out in Okta

desc: Detect a user who has been moved from suspended status in Okta
rule: User has been moved from suspended status in Okta

desc: Detect a user who has been suspended in Okta
rule: User has been suspended in Okta

desc: Detect a user who hit the rate limit on requests in Okta
rule: User hitting the rate limit on requests in Okta

desc: Detect a user who initiate an impersonation session in Okta
rule: User initiating impersonation session in Okta

desc: activity by any programs that can manage users, passwords, or permissions. sudo and su are excluded. Activity in containers is also excluded--some containers create custom users on top of a base linux distribution at startup. Some innocuous commandlines that don't actually change anything are excluded.
tags: MITRE T1068 explotation for privilege escalation

desc: Detect a password reset on a user done by Okta Admin Account
rule: User password reset by Okta admin

desc: This rule detects create/modify/delete operations on groups of users
an attempt to write to any file below a set of binary directories
tags: MITRE T1036 masquerading match legitimate name or location
MITRE T1562.001 impair defenses disable or modify tools

desc: an attempt to write to any file below /etc
tags: MITRE T1036.005 masquerading match legitimate name or location
MITRE T1562.001 impair defenses disable or modify tools

desc: an attempt to write to any file below a set of binary directories
tags: MITRE T1036.005 masquerading match legitimate name or location
MITRE T1562.001 impair defenses disable or modify tools

desc: an attempt to write to any file directly below / or /root
tags: MITRE T1036.005 masquerading match legitimate name or location
MITRE T1562.001 impair defenses disable or modify tools

desc: an attempt to write to the rpm database by any non-rpm related program
tags: MITRE T1036.005 masquerading match legitimate name or location
MITRE T1562.001 impair defenses disable or modify tools

desc: This rule detects the runtime loading of an eBPF program into the kernel. eBPF programs are extremely powerful, and as long as they conform to the constraints imposed by the eBPF verifier (ex: they don't cause a kernel panic), give near-arbitrary control over a target system.
tags: MITRE T1068 exploitation for privilege escalation
MITRE T1547.006 boot or logon autostart execution kernel modules and extensions

desc: This rule detects an attempt to elevate privileges by switching namespace context to a privileged process.
